nodes.text: PCA-based dimensionality reduction improves machine learning performance and efficiency for estimating soil moisture from hyperspectral optical imaging
Hyperspectral optical imaging produces high-dimensional, strongly correlated spectral data that exacerbate the curse of dimensionality for regression tasks
Principal Component Analysis (PCA) can reduce redundant information by projecting spectral features into uncorrelated principal components ordered by explained variance
A Random Forest regression trained on PCA-transformed hyperspectral data preserves predictive capability while improving computational efficiency
Correlation analysis and a heatmap show strong interband correlations (e.g., near 642 nm and 742 nm), indicating spectral redundancy in the measured wavelength interval

Dataset description: 679 samples collected in May 2017 from an undisturbed bare-soil sample using a Cubert UHD 285 camera producing 125 spectral bands from 450 nm to 950 nm and reference soil moisture via TRIME-PICO TDR
Data preparation: features standardized with StandardScaler, dataset split with test size 0.3 and fixed random state 42, and reproducibility ensured via numpy.random.seed(42)

PCA component selection: examination of the covariance matrix, eigenvalue distribution, and a scree plot indicated that retaining the first two principal components captures more than 99 percent of total variance
Result: PC1 variance ratio = 0.9889 and PC2 variance ratio = 0.0064 giving cumulative variance > 0.995, so PC1 and PC2 suffice to represent dominant data structure
Visualization: projection onto PC1 and PC2 shows clearer separation and clustering of samples by soil moisture, while PC2 vs PC3 shows stronger overlap consistent with low variance in PC3
Random Forest baseline: model implemented with sklearn.ensemble.RandomForestRegressor, 100 trees, test size 0.3, random state 42, performance quantified by R2
Result: Random Forest trained on PCA-transformed data achieved coefficient of determination R2 = 0.947, explaining approximately 94.7 percent of soil moisture variation
Conclusion: PCA compressed 125 spectral bands into two components while retaining over 99 percent variance, reducing redundancy and enabling efficient models without compromising predictive accuracy
Claim: PCA serves as an effective baseline dimensionality reduction approach for hyperspectral regression workflows and facilitates interpretability and scalability
Limitation and future work: the study is a single-dataset baseline; further evaluation on alternative feature extraction methods, diverse imaging scenarios, and different sensors is recommended
